claim: Modern Brazilian Navy could have hypothetically turned the tide in Battle of Actium.

supporting.text: The Brazilian Navy's modern technology, such as missile systems and radar, would be irrelevant in a naval battle from 31 BCE, as the Battle of Actium was fought with galleys and rams.

attacks.text: The Brazilian Navy's modern technology, such as missile systems and radar, would be irrelevant in a naval battle from 31 BCE, as the Battle of Actium was fought with galleys and rams.
Modern naval technology could still be adapted to ancient naval tactics, such as using missiles to target enemy galleys from a distance.
The logistical challenges of supplying modern naval vessels in 31 BCE would render their technological advantages moot.
Even if logistics were solved, the lack of infrastructure to support modern naval operations in ancient times would prevent effective deployment.
The psychological impact of modern weapons on ancient sailors could have caused mass desertion or surrender, indirectly turning the tide.
Ancient sailors might not even recognize modern weapons as threats, reducing their psychological impact.
